By chance, the Forestry Commission
acquired land,
especially in the valleys of south Wales
but in other parts of Wales as well,
which fall into what the Government
has categorised communities first areas.
These are areas which, on a scale
of disadvantage rate
particularly poorly.
That's disadvantage in terms of income,
high unemployment, poor educational attainment,
poor health and life expectancy.
The Government has committed itself
in the long term to sustain
efforts to help the lots of these communities.
Because the Forestry Commission
has, I think, something like
woodlands in 70 of the 100
communities first areas,
we're well placed to take measures
that can assist communities first,
most deprived communities.
And Forestry Enterprise
have taken this on?
We certainly have. We've taken it on with a fair bit of enthusiasm
and we've prioritised our work
in terms of putting in new
recreation facilities
so that communities perhaps that had
nowhere to walk, nowhere for mums with prams to go
have new walks, which they've helped to design.
We've contacted the schools in communities first areas
because we believe that if we talk to school children
and get them to enjoy
and perhaps have some fun outdoor sport
in the forest, that's helping them to
create a healthier lifestyle.
We've prioritised our efforts
to try to get mountain biking
and some of these activities which have a tourism potential
and can actually bring new jobs into these
most deprived areas of all. So for example,
in the Avon Valley and at Glyncorrw,
we've put in 100 kilometres of new bike
route and a new visitor centre
and there's going to be a new biking hostel
and so we are seeing jobs
come into this most deprived area
so we can hopefully raise incomes
and employment. And I have to say that
the Welsh Assembly Government finance people
are extremely keen to see forestry
often catalyse and help
community spirit develop
because often the woodlands are a topic
which can bring people together sometimes
for the first time and help engender
community spirit.
So you mentioned the Assembly.
Is it financed by them or do you get assistance from them
to cover the costs of these things?
We certainly do and since forestry
became a devolved subject just over two years ago,
the money for forestry comes
entirely from the Welsh Assembly Government
and so for
our environmental works and our social programmes
and especially for the Community First programmes,
we win our funding from the
Welsh Assembly Government.
Bob, the seed was sown
very early in your case as regards
your career with the Forest Commission. You mentioned your past
and the past and how it was, bringing us right up to date
of the projects that are going on at the moment.
Where do you think
the future lies? Are there going to be any changes of direction?
Is it going to continue as it is? Are you still
planting trees and cutting trees even?
We certainly are planting trees
and we're cutting trees, Tom, and the
economic activities of wood production
are going to continue to be important.
At the minute, the value of timber
and the things that are made in Wales from timber
amount to £400 million worth of
output a year and 4000 plus jobs
and I see that level of value
from the wood itself continuing to be
very important to the Welsh economy.
But I see as society
becomes more complex and demanding in its
expectations, so that will be additional
more complex role and sets of demands
for forestry in addition to those
wood products and that's where the challenge and the skill
of the 21st century
forester in Wales will come in,
capturing far more benefits still
for Welsh society.
I would see especially a huge increase
in the value to Wales
coming from tourism
which has been enhanced by
woodland recreation and forest landscape.
Critics of forestry had
quite rightly criticised some of the earlier
forestations. We are in a phase where we are moving towards
the forests and woodlands
complementing and enhancing
an already wonderful Welsh landscape
and my vision would perhaps
be encapsulated when the Rhondda
and the forests of the High Rhondda begin to attract
enormous numbers of tourists.
I believe the enhanced forest
and wonderful landscape we have there
and in other parts of Wales
gives us a foundation to do that.
So a huge increase in
tourism thanks to forestry.
I see a huge
increase in the diversity
of the ecology of the
woodlands of Wales. That being
intrinsically good in terms of meeting biodiversity
targets but also bringing in its wake
benefits for the Welsh environment
and some economic benefits again.
Thank you very much Bob. It's been very
interesting to talk to you. Thanks. Thank you Tom.
